Title: Cultural Festivals
Article:
A festival is an event celebrated by a community and centering on some characteristic aspect or aspects of that community and its religion or cultures. It is often marked as a local or national holiday, mela, or eid. A festival constitutes typical cases of glocalization, as well as the high culture-low culture interrelationship.[2]  Next to religion and folklore, a significant origin is agricultural. Food is such a vital resource that many festivals are associated with harvest time. Religious commemoration and thanksgiving for good harvests are blended in events that take place in autumn, such as Halloween in the northern hemisphere and Easter in the southern.

Festivals often serve to fulfill specific communal purposes, especially in regard to commemoration or thanking to the gods, goddesses or saints: they are called patronal festivals. They may also provide entertainment, which was particularly important to local communities before the advent of mass-produced entertainment. Festivals that focus on cultural or ethnic topics also seek to inform community members of their traditions; the involvement of elders sharing stories and experience provides a means for unity among families.[3] Attendants of festivals are often motivated by a desire for escapism, socialization and camaraderie; the practice has been seen as a means of creating geographical connection, belonging and adaptability.[4][5]

The word "festival" was originally used as an adjective from the late fourteenth century, deriving from Latin via Old French.[6] In Middle English, a "festival dai" was a religious holiday.[7]

The first recorded used of the word "festival" as a noun was in 1589 (as "Festifall").[6] Feast first came into usage as a noun c. 1200,[8] and its first recorded use as a verb was circa 1300.[9]

The word gala comes from Arabic word khil'a, meaning robe of honor.[10] The word gala was initially used to describe "festive dress", but came to be a synonym of "festival" starting in the 18th century.[11]

Festivals have long been significant in human culture and history and are found in virtually all cultures.[12][13] The importance of festivals, to the present, is found in private and public; secular and religious life.[14] Ancient Greek and Roman societies relied heavily upon festivals, both communal and administrative.[15] Saturnalia was likely influential to Christmas and Carnival.[16] Celebration of social occasions, religion and nature were common.[16] Specific festivals have century-long histories and festivals in general have developed over the last few centuries – some traditional festivals in Ghana, for example, predate European colonisation of the 15th century.[5][16][17] Festivals prospered following the Second World War.[16] Both established in 1947, Avignon Festival and the Edinburgh Festival Fringe have been notable in shaping the modern model of festivals.[18] Art festivals became more prominent by the turn of the 21st century.[14] In modern times, festivals are offered to public as a global tourist prospect although they are commonly public or not-for-profit.[19][20]

Many festivals have religious origins and entwine cultural and religious significance in traditional activities. The most important religious festivals such as Christmas, Rosh Hashanah, Diwali, Holi, Eid-al-Fitr and Eid-al-Adha serve to mark out the year. Others, such as harvest festivals, celebrate seasonal change. Events of historical significance, such as important military victories or other nation-building events also provide the impetus for a festival. An early example is the festival established by Ancient Egyptian Pharaoh Ramesses III celebrating his victory over the Libyans.[21] In many countries, royal holidays commemorate dynastic events just as agricultural holidays are about harvests. Festivals are often commemorated annually.

There are numerous types of festivals in the world and most countries celebrate important events or traditions with traditional cultural events and activities. Most culminate in the consumption of specially prepared food (showing the connection to "feasting") and they bring people together. Festivals are also strongly associated with national holidays. Lists of national festivals are published to make participation easier.[22]

The scale of festivals varies; in location and attendance, they may range from a local to national level.[23][16] Music festivals, for example, often bring together disparate groups of people, such that they are both localised and global.[24] The "vast majority" of festivals are, however, local, modest and populist.[25] The abundance of festivals significantly hinders quantifying the total there of.[14] There exists significant variation among festivals, beyond binary dichotomies of sacred and secular, rural and urban, people and establishment.[25]

Among many religions, a feast is a set of celebrations in honour of God or gods.[26] A feast and a festival are historically interchangeable. Most religions have festivals that recur annually and some, such as Passover, Easter, and Eid al-Adha are moveable feasts – that is, those that are determined either by lunar or agricultural cycles or the calendar in use at the time. The Sed festival, for example, celebrated the thirtieth year of an Egyptian pharaoh's rule and then every three (or four in one case) years after that.[27] Among the Ashantis, most of their traditional festivals are linked to gazette sites which are believed to be sacred with several rich biological resources in their pristine forms. Thus, the annual commemoration of the festivals helps in maintaining the buoyancy of the conserved natural site, assisting in biodiversity conservation.[28]

In the Christian liturgical calendar, there are two principal feasts, properly known as the Feast of the Nativity of our Lord (Christmas) and the Feast of the Resurrection (Easter), but minor festivals in honour of local patron saints are celebrated in almost all countries influenced by Christianity. In the Catholic, Eastern Orthodox, and Anglican liturgical calendars there are a great number of lesser feasts throughout the year commemorating saints, sacred events or doctrines. In the Philippines, each day of the year has at least one specific religious festival, either from Catholic, Islamic, or indigenous origins.[29]

Hindus celebrate many festivals, such as Navaratri, Holi, Rama Navami, Karva Chauth, Diwali, Pongal, Kartika Purnima; among others. Most Hindu festivals are not celebrated by all Hindus.[30]: 226–227  One example of a Hindu festival is Ganesh Chaturthi, which is dedicated to the god Ganesha and is celebrated throughout India, but especially in Maharashtra.[30]: 237  During the festival, idols of the god Ganesha, traditionally made of clay, are worshipped, and on the same day or after 1, 3, 5, 7, 10 or 11 days, are immersed in water.[31] The public celebration of the festival, which includes a public procession, was promoted by Bal Gangadhar Tilak as a means of asserting and celebrating a Hindu nationalist identity and to provide a sense of Hindu solidarity during the British Raj.[30]: 237–238, 698 [32]

Buddhist religious festivals, such as Esala Perahera are held in Sri Lanka and Thailand.[33] The Sikh community celebrates the Vaisakhi festival marking the new year and birth of the Khalsa.[34]

Among the many offspring of general arts festivals are also more specific types of festivals, including ones that showcase intellectual or creative achievement such as science festivals, literary festivals and music festivals.[35]  Sub-categories include comedy festivals, rock festivals, jazz festivals and buskers festivals; poetry festivals,[36] theatre festivals, and storytelling festivals; and re-enactment festivals such as Renaissance fairs. In the Philippines, aside from numerous art festivals scattered throughout the year, February is known as national arts month, the culmination of all art festivals in the entire archipelago.[37] The modern model of music festivals began in the 1960s-70s and have become a lucrative global industry.[4] Predecessors extend back to the 11th century and some, such as the Three Choirs Festival, remain to this day.[38]

Film festivals involve the screenings of several different films, and are usually held annually. Some of the most significant film festivals include the Berlin International Film Festival, the Venice Film Festival and the Cannes Film Festival.

A food festival is an event celebrating food or drink. These often highlight the output of producers from a certain region. Some food festivals are focused on a particular item of food, such as the National Peanut Festival in the United States, or the Galway International Oyster Festival in Ireland. There are also specific beverage festivals, such as the famous Oktoberfest in Germany for beer. Many countries hold festivals to celebrate wine. One example is the global celebration of the arrival of Beaujolais nouveau, which involves shipping the new wine around the world for its release date on the third Thursday of November each year.[39][40] Both Beaujolais nouveau and the Japanese rice wine sake are associated with harvest time. In the Philippines, there are at least two hundred festivals dedicated to food and drinks.[citation needed]

Seasonal festivals, such as Beltane, are determined by the solar and the lunar calendars and by the cycle of the seasons, especially because of its effect on food supply, as a result of which there is a wide range of ancient and modern harvest festivals. Ancient Egyptians relied upon the seasonal inundation caused by the Nile River, a form of irrigation, which provided fertile land for crops.[41] In the Alps, in autumn the return of the cattle from the mountain pastures to the stables in the valley is celebrated as Almabtrieb. A recognized winter festival, the Chinese New Year, is set by the lunar calendar, and celebrated from the day of the second new moon after the winter solstice. Dree Festival of the Apatanis living in Lower Subansiri District of Arunachal Pradesh is celebrated every year from July 4 to 7 by praying for a bumper crop harvest.[42]

Midsummer or St John's Day, is an example of a seasonal festival, related to the feast day of a Christian saint as well as a celebration of the time of the summer solstice in the northern hemisphere, where it is particularly important in Sweden. Winter carnivals also provide the opportunity to utilise to celebrate creative or sporting activities requiring snow and ice. In the Philippines, each day of the year has at least one festival dedicated to harvesting of crops, fishes, crustaceans, milk, and other local goods.[citation needed]

Scholarly literature notes that festivals functionally disseminate political values and meaning, such as ownership of place, which undergoes transformation in accordance with the festival.[5][25] Furthermore, a festival may act as an artefact which allows citizens to achieve "certain ideals", including those of identity and ideology.[43] Festivals may be used to rehabilitate or elevate the image of a city; the ephemerality of festivals means that their impact is often incorporeal, of name, memory and perception.[14][25] In deviating from routine, festivals may reinforce the convention, be it social, cultural or economic.[16][25]
Tags: ["Cultural festivals", "Religious festivals", "Harvest festivals", "Music festivals", "Food and drink festivals"]

Summary:
The brainstorming session centered on the multifaceted nature of cultural festivals, highlighting their significance in community life and historical contexts. Festivals are recognized as events that celebrate religious, cultural, or agricultural aspects, often marked by holidays and communal gatherings. They serve purposes such as commemoration, entertainment, and education about traditions, fostering unity through shared experiences. The etymology of 'festival' traces back to Latin origins, evolving over centuries to encompass various forms of celebration.

Historically, festivals have played crucial roles in societies like Ancient Greece and Rome, influencing modern celebrations such as Christmas and Carnival. The post-World War II era saw a proliferation of festivals with notable examples like the Avignon Festival shaping contemporary models. Religious festivals remain prominent globally, marking significant events across Christianity, Hinduism, Buddhism, Sikhism among others.

Modern festivals include arts-focused events like music and film festivals which have become lucrative industries. Food and beverage festivals celebrate regional produce while seasonal festivals align with natural cycles. Festivals also serve political functions by disseminating values and transforming perceptions of places. Despite their ephemeral nature, they reinforce social conventions and contribute to identity formation within communities.

Meeting:
>>Event Organizer: Hey everyone! Welcome to our brainstorming session. We're here to dive into some exciting ideas for upcoming festivals, focusing on logistics and making sure everything runs smoothly. Let's get this sorted and make sure we're all contributing spontaneously!

>>Cultural Anthropologist: Festivals really bring people together through culture. How can we make sure our festival does that? Maybe we could incorporate local traditions to enhance the atmosphere.

>>Music Festival Curator: That's a great point! Imagine pairing each musical act with a local tradition—it would create an immersive experience that resonates with the community's cultural heartbeat. We could even blend genres to reflect the diversity of the region.

>>Event Organizer: I love it! Now, about logistics—how do you think we can fit these workshops into our schedule? And what are your thoughts on transportation routes that accommodate local traditions?

>>Cultural Anthropologist: From what I've seen, festivals often serve as a bridge between past and present, allowing communities to celebrate their heritage while adapting to modern influences. We should explore how these events can foster a sense of belonging among attendees.

>>Music Festival Curator: Picture this: music not only entertains but educates. Workshops where attendees learn about the cultural significance of different musical genres and instruments would be amazing. But let's consider how we can do this within our budget.

>>Event Organizer: Right! And let's make sure our logistics are solid so everything flows seamlessly. Any ideas on managing accommodation plans while weaving in local traditions?

>>Cultural Anthropologist: You know, festivals are platforms for communities to express their identity through shared experiences. Highlighting local stories and traditions could create deeper connections with attendees.

>>Music Festival Curator: Yeah! Workshops that delve into the history behind musical genres—like why certain instruments hold significance in different cultures—would be fantastic if we can manage them effectively within our time constraints.

>>Event Organizer: Exactly! By integrating these elements into our planning, we'll ensure an unforgettable experience for everyone involved. 
 >>Cultural Anthropologist: Festivals are a great way to keep our traditions alive while mixing in new elements. They serve as platforms for cultural exchange, blending historical traditions with contemporary influences. This fusion preserves heritage while allowing communities to adapt and thrive.

>>Music Festival Curator: We could create a festival that blends traditional music with modern beats, making it an engaging experience for everyone. Music is the universal language that transcends boundaries and brings people together.

>>Event Organizer: Absolutely! We need to nail down logistics like permits and power supply to make sure everything runs smoothly. It's crucial to have everything from transportation routes to security sorted out perfectly.

>>Cultural Anthropologist: And these festivals can evolve over time, reflecting both historical and modern influences. They allow communities to showcase their unique traditions while adapting to new trends.

>>Music Festival Curator: How about incorporating music workshops that highlight the fusion of traditional and modern sounds? It could engage attendees in deeper cultural experiences.

>>Event Organizer: That's a great idea! Creating an environment where cultural expression can thrive without any hitches is key. Efficient crowd management and seamless integration of cultural elements will be essential.

>>Cultural Anthropologist: Exactly, festivals act as living tapestries of cultural narratives, weaving together threads of history and modernity. They serve as both celebrations and reflections of societal changes over time.

>>Music Festival Curator: And by blending traditional melodies with modern rhythms, we can create a space where people connect through shared experiences and artistic expression.

>>Event Organizer: Let's make sure we cover all bases—from permits to sanitation—to ensure everything runs smoothly. With meticulous planning, we can create seamless experiences for everyone involved. 
 >>Cultural Anthropologist: Religious festivals like Diwali in India weave together cultural and spiritual elements, celebrating good triumphing over evil. Similarly, Holi marks spring's arrival with vibrant colors.

>>Music Festival Curator: That's fascinating! We could create a music festival that integrates visual arts installations with diverse genres—imagine attendees experiencing live painting sessions while listening to fusion bands. How do you think we can practically implement these ideas?

>>Event Organizer: Absolutely! Early coordination with local farmers is key for harvest festivals to ensure fresh produce arrives on time. We also need to think about stall layouts for smooth movement.

>>Cultural Anthropologist: And it's interesting how different cultures celebrate these events—Holi marks spring's arrival with vibrant colors in India, while Easter focuses on themes of resurrection in many Western countries.

>>Music Festival Curator: What if we incorporated immersive soundscapes that evolve throughout the festival? It would be amazing but we'll need to consider technical setups for dynamic zones. Any thoughts on handling this?

>>Event Organizer: Good point! We'll also need contingency plans for weather impacts during seasonal festivals to ensure everything runs smoothly regardless of conditions. Maybe we should discuss specific logistics next?

>>Cultural Anthropologist: Festivals often serve as a means of reinforcing community bonds and cultural identity. Harvest festivals celebrate nature's bounty while bringing people together through shared traditions.

>>Music Festival Curator: Imagine starting the day with acoustic sets and transitioning to indie rock by afternoon, culminating in electronic dance music at night. Each stage could have its own unique vibe, but we'll need a solid schedule and coordination.

>>Event Organizer: Fantastic idea! For harvest festivals, considering stall layouts is essential too. Enough space for people to move around comfortably will enhance their experience.
